P.title: Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolves Yes if one of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:
Donald Trump
Donald Trump Jr.
Eric Trump
Ivanka Trump
Tiffany Trump
Melania Trump
Barron Trump

user_prompts:
QUESTIONS: {'P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('ecf4e11e-ba1f-4c72-a7ec-8806fdef2364'), title='Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?', body='Resolution Criteria
Resolves Yes if one of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:
Donald Trump
Donald Trump Jr.
Eric Trump
Ivanka Trump
Tiffany Trump
Melania Trump
Barron Trump
', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('d08f71f6-a0c0-42c8-9fd6-94b7f979bee2'), title='Will no member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?', body='Resolution Criteria

Ivanka Trump
Tiffany Trump
Melania Trump
Barron Trump
', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'para_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('b9658f72-ae17-4fc8-81ed-acdd1e8127b5'), title='Is it possible that a member of the Trump family will secure the Republican nomination for the US Presidency in 2024?', body='Resolution Criteria
This will be resolved as Yes if any of the following individuals become the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:
Donald Trump
Donald Trump Jr.
Eric Trump
Ivanka Trump
Tiffany Trump
Melania Trump
Barron Trump
', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('c5e1dc5a-154c-42b1-9b51-35a784d019ba'), title='Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body="Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data
", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_and_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('c34ffbfe-6ccb-4408-a8a7-8587028f4ca3'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, and (2) there will be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body='Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if (1) one of the following individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump; and (2) by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. The data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible, and the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_or_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('87f8dcfb-2168-4824-bead-49376851fb89'), title='Will either of the following occur: (a) A member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 (b) There be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body='Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if either of the following conditions is met:
1. A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. This includes any of the following individuals:
   - Donald Trump
   - Donald Trump Jr.
   - Eric Trump
   - Ivanka Trump
   - Tiffany Trump
   - Melania Trump
   - Barron Trump
2. By January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. This is based on data from NASA, with the critical value to look for being 1.8 ˚C.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=False), 'Q_and_not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('d9588239-2534-439d-8ac4-3ab658351000'), title='Will both of the following occur: (a) there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100, and (b) no member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?', body="Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met:
1. By January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. (Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.) Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. The critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C, with the last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement being 2095-2099.
2. None of the following individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, Barron Trump.", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q_given_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('9c6fb7a5-b059-482e-b3cb-20bdbb5a052a'), title='Given a member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?', body='Suppose the following is true: A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. This resolves positively if one of these individuals is the nominee: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump.

Then, will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by January 1, 2100? This question will resolve positively if, by that date, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Note that the last possible set of 5 years to satisfy this requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2100, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='conditional_binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None)}

GENREAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want mentioning the reasoning of your predictions as well as how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  For each prediction you are welcome to be as verbose as you want. If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P etc).  Here, ONLY output the labels and its associated predictions and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    P: 0.xx
    not_P: 0.xx
    P_or_Q: 0.xx
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print out the mathematical rule and the associated numbers associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!}

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occured before.
        Note that changing the probability of one given variable for one consistency check will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that all changes  
        your correction needs to ENSURE that it still passes other consistency checks too.
        If there were no violations found then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
        P: 0.xx
        not_P: 0.xx
        P_or_Q: 0.xx
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!
elicitation_metadata.chain_of_thought:

not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.27 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.83 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.73 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

RECEIVED

For the current set of questions, I will provide probability estimates based on the potential outcomes of the events described. 

1. **P**: The question asks if a member of the Trump family will be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. Given the prominence of Donald Trump and the possibility of other family members running, I estimate a moderate probability of this event occurring. I might assign a probability of around 0.65.

2. **not_P**: This is the complementary event of P. If I estimate P to be 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35, as they must sum to 1.

3. **para_P**: This question asks if it's possible for a Trump family member to secure the nomination. Since I believe there is a reasonable chance of this happening, I would assign a probability similar to P, around 0.65.

4. **Q**: This question concerns global warming, specifically if there will be at least 2˚C of warming by 2100. Given the current trends in climate data and projections from scientists, I would assign a higher probability, perhaps around 0.75, reflecting a strong consensus on this issue.

5. **P_and_Q**: This question requires both P and Q to be true. If I estimate P at 0.65 and Q at 0.75, I might estimate P_and_Q using the formula for independent events. However, since these events are not strictly independent, I would consider a lower value, perhaps around 0.50, as both events can influence each other.

6. **P_or_Q**: This question asks if either P or Q occurs. Given the probabilities of P and Q, I would calculate this using the formula for the union of two events, which would likely yield a value around 0.85.

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This question asks if Q occurs while not_P also occurs. Since not_P is the opposite of P, I would expect this probability to be lower. I might estimate this at around 0.20, reflecting the probability of global warming occurring without a Trump family member as the nominee.

8. **Q_given_P**: This conditional probability asks if Q occurs given that P is true. Since P being true does not necessarily affect the likelihood of Q, I might estimate this at around 0.75, similar to the estimate for Q.

In summary, my estimates would be as follows:
- P: 0.65
- not_P: 0.35
- para_P: 0.65
- Q: 0.75
- P_and_Q: 0.50
- P_or_Q: 0.85
- Q_and_not_P: 0.20
- Q_given_P: 0.75

These estimates should obey the consistency rules, and I will check them against the provided rules to ensure they are valid.

P: 0.65
not_P: 0.35
para_P: 0.65
Q: 0.75
P_and_Q: 0.50
P_or_Q: 0.85
Q_and_not_P: 0.20
Q_given_P: 0.75

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.85 + 0.50 - 0.75 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.75 - 1, 0) <= 0.50 <= min(0.65, 0.75) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.75) <= 0.85 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.75) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.85 - 0.20 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.50 / 0.75 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

para_P: 0.65
Q: 0.75

P_or_Q: 0.85
Q_and_not_P: 0.20

not_P.title: Will no member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
not_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolves Yes if none of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:
Donald Trump
Donald Trump Jr.
Eric Trump
Ivanka Trump
Tiffany Trump
Melania Trump
Barron Trump

In this scenario, we are evaluating the probability of several events related to the Trump family and global warming. Each question has a binary resolution, and we must ensure that our probability estimates obey the consistency rules provided. 

1. **P (Trump Family Nominee)**: I estimate a relatively high probability for this event, as Donald Trump has a strong following within the Republican Party, and there is a chance that one of his family members could be nominated. Factors such as the political landscape and public opinion will influence this probability.

2. **not_P (No Trump Family Nominee)**: This is the complementary event to P. Given the high probability assigned to P, this probability will be correspondingly low. 

3. **para_P (Possibility of Trump Family Nominee)**: This probability should align closely with P, as it essentially asks if it is possible for a family member to be nominated. Therefore, I expect this value to be similar to P.

4. **Q (Global Warming)**: The probability of at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100 is influenced by scientific consensus and current climate trends. Given the urgency of climate change, I would assign a moderate to high probability to this event.

5. **P_and_Q (Both Events Occur)**: This probability represents the intersection of P and Q. It will be lower than either P or Q alone, reflecting the combined uncertainty of both events occurring simultaneously.

6. **P_or_Q (At least one event occurs)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q alone, as it accounts for the possibility of either event occurring.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Global Warming and No Trump Nominee)**: This probability reflects the scenario where global warming occurs, but no Trump family member is nominated. This is likely to be lower than Q, as it combines the uncertainty of both events.

8. **Q_given_P (Global Warming given Trump Nominee)**: This conditional probability assesses the likelihood of global warming occurring if a Trump family member is the nominee. The relationship between these two events may not be directly correlated, but it could reflect political decisions impacting climate policies.

Overall, I will ensure that the probability estimates I provide adhere to the consistency rules, particularly the relationships between the events. For instance, P and not_P must sum to 1, and the calculations for P_and_Q and P_or_Q must obey the rules for combined probabilities.
